text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with easy one bowl hollandaise
that's right it's true this new method
i've developed for making hollandaise
only requires one bowl and is by far the
easiest method I've ever used
and by the way I'm not talking
physically easier I'm talking mentally
easier because what you're about to see
requires just as much whisking in time
as the traditional method but we've
eliminated all those variables that
usually mess people up in fact all we're
going to do here is dump everything into
a bowl and whisk it over low heat until
we have hollandaise and I realize that
might sound a little far-fetched but
check it out it totally works so we're
going to start by tossing one large egg
yolk into a stainless steel bowl and
usually we cook the egg yolk first and
then complete the sauce by whisking in
hot melted butter but not with this
technique like I said we're just going
to dump everything into the bowl
including our cold butter which has been
cubed up we'll just add that right to
the raw oh and yet has some where our
culinary instructor just spit out their
coffee but anyway we're going to
continue on adding the rest of the
ingredients which includes a nice big
pinch of salt as well as a little bit of
cayenne or you could use a few drips of
hot sauce here that's up to you you are
the Richard Blais of your hollandaise so
you decide but a little bit of heat is
highly recommended and then we're going
to finish up with a couple liquid
ingredients which really are the secret
to making this technique work we're
going to add a splash of cold fresh
water just a couple tablespoons as well
as a tablespoon of freshly squeezed
lemon juice and then what we'll do once
we have all our ingredients in this bowl
is we'll take a whisk and give it a
little mix which reminds me I'm making
the smallest batch possible just using
one egg yolk but if you're going to
scale this up for a bigger batch I'd
probably mix everything first and then
add the butter cubes last just so it's a
little easier here it didn't matter and
then all we're going to do is take this
over to the stove where we are going to
cook this over low heat stirring pretty
much continually until about ten or
fifteen minutes later we have
hollandaise so we're going to whisk with
one hand while we carefully hold the
bowl with a towel in the other in one
pro tip do not let that towel catch on
fire that will not fill your brunch
guests with confidence so be careful but
anyway we're going to continue to cook
that over low heat whisking pretty much
the whole time I mean you can take a
couple couple second breaks but this is
not something you can just let sit over
the heat
and at the beginning here now lots going
to happen the butter is going to kind of
slowly melt into the mixture but just
keep cooking in a stir in and you'll see
after a few minutes it'll start to get
sort of foamy and start to thicken up a
little bit and all we're going to do is
simply continue until it's as thick as
we want and I guess part of that is what
you're going to serve this on see we
could stop right about here since that's
looking pretty good what we have right
here would be just about perfect for
Eggs Benedict but since I'm going to put
this over some asparagus I wanted a
little thicker so I cook mine for
another minute or two until it looked
like this check it out just so
beautifully thick and luxurious in fact
let me grab a spoon so we can get a
better look and by the way I didn't show
it but of course you're going to taste
this for seasoning before you serve it
up that's just common sense so I did
give mine a taste off camera and it was
perfect which means we can serve this up
in my case on some gorgeous pan roasted
asparagus and by the way as with all
hollandaise sauce is if you're not going
to use this right away you got to keep
it warm on the back of the stove just
cover it with foil and leave it
somewhere warm it'll be fine and if
you're doing this at home you could just
dump over that sauce see what I'm doing
is trying to make it look sexy for the
picture which didn't really work but I
tried and then I finished that up with
an extra touch of cayenne and that's it
our easy One Bowl hollandaise is ready
to enjoy and I'm not exactly sure why I
have a fork and knife here since
according to those etiquette people it
is totally appropriate to eat asparagus
with your fingers yes even in a
restaurant so let me grab one and try
this out and forget about what method we
used that is just one perfect
hollandaise I mean so often you run
across these shortcut methods that are
easier but do not give you the same
results as the classic methods and yet
here not only was the technique much
simpler and more foolproof but the
results are as good if not better than
the classic method and even though I
didn't need that fork to eat this I will
use it to give you one last look here at
that perfect texture for me a perfectly
made hollandaise has to be thick and yet
at the same time light which is not
always the case but here totally the
case so I just absolutely love how this
comes out I think just a genius way to
make what can be a problematic sauce and
no I didn't just call myself a genius I
said the technique is genius although I
did come up with this technique so I
will let you draw your own conclusions
but regardless I really do hope you give
this a try soon so head over to food
wishes calm for all the ingredient
amounts and more info as usual and as
always enjoy
